newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU seeks breakthrough on European company law.
newsitem.headline: EU seeks breakthrough on European company law.

text.p: A high-level group set up by the European Commission gave fresh hope on Tuesday of breaking a 20-year deadlock on draft EU corporate law which would allow firms to set up as European companies rather than national ones.
The EU executive published a report by a group of labour experts suggesting ways out of the impasse over the main stumbling block of worker involvement in firms' decisions.

EU heavyweights Germany and Britain have held conflicting views on this issue, blocking progress on the Commission's proposal for a European company statute intended to make life easier for industry and to slash administrative costs.

EU Internal Market Commissioner Mario Monti welcomed the Davignon group's report, saying it was a "key contribution to making a breakthrough on this project to which the Commission remains faithful after 25 years of difficulties."
"It's the first opportunity for years to break the deadlock," said EU Social Affairs Commissioner Padraig Flynn.
There is considerable pressure from industry for a European company statute, seen as a way to boost efficiency.

"It is a significant factor in strengthening Europe's industry. We waste all over Europe too much money on administrative costs," Keith Richardson, secretary-general of the European Round Table of Industrialists, told Reuters.

The main conflict blocking a deal has involved provisions on worker participation in company decisions, with Bonn promoting its own system of "co-determination" between employees and managers and London arguing there should be no mandatory rules.

Seeking to resolve the row, the Davignon group, headed by Etienne Davignon, the chairman of Belgian holding company Societe Generale and a former European Commissioner, proposed that unions and employers should first try to agree on the worker involvement for each such European company.

"It is only in the absence of an agreement between these parties that a set of reference rules would apply, covering both information/consultation and the participation of workers in the relevant company bodies," a statement said.
Flynn and Monti said the solutions suggested in the report formed a good basis for a fresh start of the debate.

"They are designed to meet the concerns of all the interested parties, by opening up the prospect of a new option for companies and a legal framework to cover their European operations, while maintaining an important social dimension."

It was not clear whether Britain's new Labour government, which has said it will join up to the EU's Social Chapter, would change London's position on the issue. "The new government has not yet considered the proposal," an official said.
Monti and Flynn set up the Davignon group last November.
The report will be presented to the European Commission on Wednesday, to EU Internal Market Ministers on May 21 and to EU Social Affairs Ministers on June 12.
A European company statute would provide for the creation of a 'European company' operating on a Europe-wide basis and subject to a single EU law applicable in all 15 member states.
Businesses established in more than one member state would not need to set up a complex network of subsidiaries governed by different national laws, allowing for major savings in costs.

Under the proposal by the EU executive, a European company could be formed in different ways, for example through a merger between at least two companies from two or more member states, or by companies from two EU countries or more forming a holding company or a subsidiary. -- Brussels newsroom +32 2 287 68 11
